title: Data Visualisations
text:
Visualisation no 4??

How we did the visualisation


Our insights

In this project we examine two major questions.

Is there a relationship between economic periods and art?
Do social movements, like Black Lives Matter have an impact on the kinds of art created?

In this project we examine two major questions.

Is there a relationship between economic periods and art?
Do social movements, like Black Lives Matter have an impact on the kinds of art created?

Our motivations for this project
Historically, art has tended to flourish in times of economic prosperity, while during periods of economic hardship, art themes tend to shift. By tracking GDP over the past century, we hope to identify these economic shifts and see if they align with changes in the art themes that are popular during those times. As students who are very familiar with social media, we also thought it would be interesting to see how recent social movements impact art.

title: Data Collection
text: Our process

title: Data Collection
text:
Challenges faced







Challenge
How we dealt with the challenge




Finding a data that contained historical data for social movements.
Tried Reddit, X and Open Sanction but encountered issues due to lack of historical data or paywalls. Eventually chose GDELT to get data from 2014 onwards.


Initially we could only collect 100 artworks of data from Simthsonian API.
Further research and using different endpoints


Encountered issues in trying to get data from 1929 onwards from Smithsonian API due to rate limit
By limiting the range of data collected to match with GDELT data (from 2014 onwards)

title: Data Collection
text: Response to challenges

title: Data Collection
text:
Global Database of Events, Laguage and Tone (GDELT)

It gathers news from a wide range of sources, including smaller media outlets, which helps capture emerging grassroots movements.
Analyses the tone of media coverage, giving us insight into how people and the media are reacting to these events
Has historical data which allows us to track how movements grow and change over time
The platform makes it easy to visualize trends and connections, helping us make sense of complex information. 

Smithsonian

It is the world’s biggest museum complex with 21 museums (and other educational centres) spanning the United States
Has numerous art pieces in its collections, which allows us to make accurate conclusions on whether the art themes artists choose to create their art in have been impacted by the state of the economy
It is reliable as the institution is committed to rigorous scholarly research so many artworks in the Smithsonian’s collection have been thoroughly researched by experts in the field

Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED)

It has data for America on GDP from 1929, which allowed us to look at a larger time period compared to other APIs
This database always contains the most recent version of the data available

title: Data Collection
text: Data Collection Process

title: Data Processing
text:
The general process was to:

Filter to get relevant columns
Rename columns to improve clarity
Save to a SQLite database

For GDP data we processed the data to have GDP per decade rather than yearly for more insightful visualisations
